East Rochester Music Department is at East Rochester Junior-Senior High School.
September 11 at 11:17 PM · East Rochester, NY ·

We’re celebrating the end of the first “week“ of school, and here’s a special treat: A sneak peek of the new 6-8 bandroom! This room is nearly finished, and construction is continuing in the new HS band room, office and practice space, and other areas of the building outside of school hours. Currently set up for a 48 piece band, with room to spare. If you are concerned about how close the seats are – we set up the room just for photos, and will have about 20% of the current chairs and stands when we begin using it with social distancing. Looking forward to the day we can start using this room with students, and especially to the day we can put the entire band in there.

June 8, 2020 - Budget Vote Deadline Extended

New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a new executive order on Sunday, June 7 for the annual School Budget Vote and Board Elections.

The order extends it for any received by mail to June 16. However, all hand-delivered ballots must still be submitted by 5 p.m. tomorrow, Tuesday, June 9. East Rochester residents have the option to submit their ballots in a secure drop box outside the District Office until 5 p.m. on June 9 only.

Ballots for additional household members who are qualified voters can be requested by contacting the district clerk at Kristen.adler@erschools.org or 248-6302 x1. There will be no additional ballot requests after 5 p.m. on June 9.

As you know, all voting this year is by absentee ballot only due to the COVID-10 pandemic.

For more information about the proposed budget, please visit: http://www.erschools.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=240396&pageId=25834503

Thank you to Image City for its efforts to create this alternative way to recognize the area’s talented student artists!

Link to the Virtual Student Show:
http://www.imagecityphotographygallery.com/Shows/202004show/

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Annual School Budget Vote and Board Election has been rescheduled for Tues., June 9, 2020. All voting will take place by absentee ballot pursuant to the Governor’s Executive Order. Ballots will be mailed to residents homes and must be returned to the district clerk by 5pm on Tuesday, June 9, 2020 to be valid.

Anyone who wishes to run for the Board of Education must submit a letter of intent by Monday, May 11 to the district clerk. Biographical information and photo must be submitted to the district clerk by 5 PM on May 7 to meet printing deadlines.

For more information, please visit http://www.erschools.org/news/what_s_new/board_candidate_information

Dear ER Community:

Yesterday I sent you my weekly update. In my update I shared that as per Executive Order 202.14 Governor Cuomo directed that school will remain closed until April 29th. Yesterday, April 16, 2020, Governor Cuomo outlined his blueprint to “un-pause” New York, getting people back to work and erasing social isolation without triggering renewed spread of the virus.

Governor Cuomo’s first step is to “Do NO Harm” to continue controlling the rate of infection. As per Governor Cuomo this includes extending the “NY Pause” order until May 15th. This order includes the wearing of masks in public and it also means that our school will remain closed through May 15th.

In closing, I again want to thank you for your support and more importantly your patience.

Sincerely,
Richard G. Stutzman, Jr.
Interim Superintendent of Schools

Clearly we are in the midst of challenging times. We are all working to navigate unknown situations at work, at school, and at home. Please know that the health and safety of our students and staff will continue to be the priority in all decisions.

I want to thank everyone for your patience and understanding.

Sincerely yours,
Richard G. Stutzman, Jr.

ER was honored to welcome distinguished guest, Helen Levinson, to the school this afternoon. Not a sound could be heard in the auditorium as the Holocaust survivor shared her story of survival, resilience, hope and overcoming hatred with our grades 8-12 students.

A photo of herself as a little girl with her brother and sister, a prayer book and some Polish money given to her by her father the last time she saw him in 1942 are all Mrs. Levinson has left of her family. Today, she beams when talking about her son, daughter, grandchildren and great grandchildren.

Mrs. Levinson encouraged our students to always reject hatred and show kindness to one another.

“I want young people to know what hatred can do,” she said. “When you can be a nice to a person, try your very best.”

Ina Vento's kindergarten class had so much fun during their 100th Day Celebration before the break!

Using their pincer grasp they counted ten beads and threaded them onto a necklace. "The kids were persistent, patient and proud to wear their necklace."

Using gloves, the kids also went around gathering ten groups of ten different snacks. "Some of the kids were surprised all those snacks fit in each bag. On our 100th Day Snack board we used beginning sounds to read each snack name, used our pincer grasp to sort and counted each snack to ten. We were VERY impressed with how honest the kids were when they had 1 of to many or needed 1 more to make ten."

#100daysofschool

Saxophonist Isabella Alexander has become East Rochester's first student to ever be named 1st chair in the All County Band and 1st chair in the All County Jazz Band! No ER student has ever attained this combined recognition during their school career, let alone in the same year. Isabella achieved this by simultaneously preparing and then performing both jazz and classical level 6 solos, the hardest-possible level of solo, as an 8th grader. On her two prepared solos, Isabella combined for a total score of 169 out of 170.

We are so proud of you, Isabella!
